newsitem.title: CHINA: Yuan ends up against US dollar in Shanghai.
newsitem.headline: Yuan ends up against US dollar in Shanghai.

text.p: The Chinese yuan closed up at 8.2924 on Friday from Thursday's 8.2928 against the U.S. dollar, recovering from a technical correction in the past two days due to strong pro-yuan sentiment, traders said.
The weighted average price on Thursday was 8.2923.

The yuan opened down at an intraday low of 8.2930 and rose slightly to move around 8.2925 for most of the session, hitting a high of 8.2918. Trading was dull ahead of the weekend with most business done at 8.2923, traders said.
One dealer said the yuan re-gained its upward momentum on Friday after the technical correction.
"More buying was seen after the yuan touched the intraday low at the opening," he said. "But due to the weekend factor, the yuan failed to breach the 8.2920 level at the close."
A second dealer said the new foreign exchange reserve figures boosted pro-yuan sentiment.
The local media on Thursday reported that China's foreign exchange reserves hit $115 billion at the end of April, an increase of only $3 billion over the end of March.
"The growth of the reserves apparently slowed down in April after months of rapid rises," the second dealer said. "This indicated the central bank is intervening less on the market."
"If the central bank continues to reduce its activity to depress the yuan, the yuan is likely to set new highs due to increasing demand," he said.
The central bank, the People's Bank, has intervened on a daily basis since the market was establish two years ago to prevent the yuan from rising sharply.
Dealers said they expected the yuan to move around the 8.2920 level early next week.
The yuan ended up at 7.1866 from 7.2060 against 100 Japanese yen and up at an intraday high of 1.0705 from 1.0721 against the Hong Kong dollar. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
